repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Forestry Institutions and
            Conservation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Forestry Institutions
            and Conservation Project for Indonesia were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, project sustainability was
            uncertain, Bank performance was satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: sustainability in a large forest resource can only
            be developed over a long term, integrated and sequenced
            involvement in the sector: to the extent possible, provision
            should be made for this kind of long term Bank involvement
            right from the beginning of the initial operation. Inputs to
            enhance the technical and human resources capacity of
            forestry agencies to deal with the fundamental problem of
            long-term sustainability of Indonesia's forest will
            have limited impact in the longer run if concomitant shifts
            in policies and incentives are not introduced by the
            governments. Project launch workshop should be organized to
            train key project staff in Bank's practice and
            procedures on procurement, management, particularly when
            dealing with agencies that have had little experience in
            Bank operations. Decentralization of watershed management
            activities at the district level, and a highly competent
            district level administration are important factors in the
            successful implementation of such initiatives.

5078536.admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Forestry Institutions and
            Conservation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Forestry Institutions and
            Conservation project will strengthen forestry planning and
            management by: (a) developing appropriate strategies for
            forest management; (b) strengthening forestry research; (c)
            strengthening information for subsectoral planning; (d)
            improving the Ministry of Forest's (MOF) manpower
            development planning and training capacity; and (e)
            preparing investment projects consistant with subsectoral
            strategy recommendations. It will also improve watershed
            conservation measures in the Upper Solo (Wongiri) watershed
            in Central Java, considered to be the most critical
            watershed in Indonesia because of erosion and high
            population density. Finally, it will strengthen management
            of five existing nature conservation areas, including buffer
            zone development to preclude exploitation by local
            inhabitants and technical assisstance for developing models
            for nationwide replication. Economic benefits expected are
            longer-term production from the forestry sector, more
            efficient and higher levels of output and incomes from the
            sector, better sustenance of the natural environment, and
            increased agricultural production, longer dam life, and
            lower irrigation costs in Wonogiri..
